data.title: Don't show TypeScript version in Status Bar for JavaScript Projects
data.body:
#21037

In a JS project without any `jsconfig.json` (like 90% of the projects I work on), you see the TS version in the status bar (which is very verbose on Insiders):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23234231/43ff31c6-f906-11e6-88ab-59d98fe42044.png)

Clicking it gives the following:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23234207/2a4c4aac-f906-11e6-8657-3d9953177e59.png)

Why are we presenting this information at all if there is nothing to action such as in a project without a workspace version of TypeScript? This information is neither useful or easy to understand for JavaScript developers. We could remove the clutter when it's not relevant:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23234344/a5470b20-f906-11e6-91fe-0199e70a76b4.png)

data.title: [html] Format onPaste issues with HTML
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an HTML document like below
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6901336/23234152/bf43b8d8-f916-11e6-95eb-fefe6f309a7c.png)

2. Copy the `nested-content` div
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6901336/23234205/ecf75ef6-f916-11e6-8569-13e1c7238101.png)

3. Since we copied the spacing on the left (along with the text), we should be able to place our cursor to the very left and paste (or even just paste). Instead of the correct formatting we get something like this:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6901336/23234281/2e47d3fe-f917-11e6-9bd8-ca64a5689e00.png)

   or this (without moving the text cursor)
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6901336/23234306/47277884-f917-11e6-9c54-b7bd6020f27d.png)

I assume this is an issue with the newer format feature, but I could be wrong.

data.title: TS version in status bar is confusing
data.body:
#21037

It looked to me like that's VS Code's version initially.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23234047/ad740420-f905-11e6-91bb-8d5105f6903f.png)

Why not use something like "Bundled TS" or something to more more useful and obvious what it really is. Users probably don't care the exact version number and it just adds visual noise.

data.title: Focusing debug console or output hides TypeScript version being used in status bar
data.body:
#21037

It's strange to see the status bar jump around like this, especially when you click the debug console's monaco editor (the status bar item hides on mousedown, and show on mouseup).

It's happening because output and debug console are using monaco editors. The status bar item should show based on the last active editor, not the currently active monaco instance.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23233899/29c8019e-f905-11e6-9ee7-a879dc975cb9.png)

data.title: Pressing configure excludes button presents another configure excludes button
data.body:
#21037

Pressing this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23233721/9385282e-f904-11e6-9e3a-35cb82253be3.png)

Presents:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23233731/9a95e41e-f904-11e6-89bf-d4deccd841e3.png)

I've already committed to configuring them, why do I need to press it twice?

data.title: Why is VS Code telling me to configure excludes when intellisense seems to work fine without it
data.body:
#21037

On this repo https://github.com/gwtw/js-fibonacci-heap I'm being told to configure excludes in the status bar which tells me:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23233661/66c9c722-f904-11e6-80ca-9afa9ce3d5bb.png)

Why do I need to do this when intellisense seems to work fine without it?

data.title: git keyword not working in command pallet when SCM Preview is enabled
data.body:
Testing #20999

- type "git " in the command pallet

Expected: git related commands show up
Actual: quick open for files is shown

data.title: JavaScript go to configuration goes to wrong config
data.body:
#21037

On following repo: https://github.com/gwtw/js-fibonacci-heap

Steps to reproduce:

1. JavaScript go to configuration, create jsconfig.json as `{}`
2. Copy `./jsconfig.json` to `./test/jsconfig.json`
3. Open `./test/clear-test.js`
4. JavaScript go to configuration, `./jsconfig.json` is opened. I expected `./test/jsconfig.json` to be opened.

data.title: TypeScript go to configuration does nothing
data.body:
#21037

Related to #21210

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open ./index.js
2. Trigger *JavaScript* go to configuration
3. Create a new file and save it as an empty jsconfig.json
4. Open ./index.js
5. Trigger *TypeScript* go to configuration, nothing happens. I was expecting it to create a tsconfig.json file similar to step 3.

data.title: JavaScript go to configuration does nothing
data.body:
#21037

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open ./index.js
2. Trigger JavaScript go to configuration
3. Create a new file and save it as an empty jsconfig.js
4. Open ./index.js
5. Trigger JavaScript go to configuration again

It's not 100% clear from the documentation but I read it as a minimal jsconfig.json would implicitly include all files in the directory:

> By default the JavaScript language service will analyze and provide IntelliSense for all files in your JavaScript project. You will want to specify which files to exclude or include in order to provide the proper IntelliSense.

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/jsconfig

data.title: Default jsconfig/tsconfig should have content
CodeLens and Data Annotations
data.body:
This is a bit of a feature request/not quite a bug...
- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.0-insider (1.10.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac OS

Currently, CodeLens in the Model classes sticks right above the POCO. But when I add annotations, I get the CodeLens in between the POCO and the Annotation, and when I have a couple of them, it gets confusing: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12577765/23231608/6df1bef8-f916-11e6-8132-6d9b4fa935fe.png)

What I would like to see is that the CodeLens be included above the annotation for the POCO, so that it's all treated as a single unit: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12577765/23232105/1bec87f8-f918-11e6-81c4-6709f65524b7.png)

Thank you for all of the great work you do!

data.title: Compare Directory & All Files Within Directory / SSH Terminal / DB Manager
data.body:
Would love to see these options available:

Compare Directory & All Files Within Directory - (PHPStorm style)
Remote SSH Terminal
DB Manager

data.title: Windows + VSCode + Bash
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.9.1 - OS Version: Windows 7 Hi. I use VSCode (and it's awesome by the way!) in a portable way for school (Java plugin). I have this structure: _ workspace _ git ___ bin _____ bash _ vscode ___ data _____ User _______ `settings.json` > "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "../../git/bin/bash.exe" _ `script.bash` I run vscode with this command vscode\code --user-data-dir vscode/data --extensionHomePath vscode/extensions workspace Everythings is working perfectfy. But when I wanted to add a bash script at run with this "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["--init-file script.bash"] the console just open and instantly close. I just want to make an alias for example `alias ..=cd ..`

data.title: Close Affordance flag is ignored on Linux
data.body: While testing #21004. ```typescript vscode.window.showInformationMessage('hello world', { modal: true }, { title: 'A', isCloseAffordance: false } as vscode.MessageItem, { title: 'B', isCloseAffordance: false } as vscode.MessageItem, { title: 'C', isCloseAffordance: true } as vscode.MessageItem, ); ``` correctly generates while ```typescript vscode.window.showInformationMessage('hello world', { modal: true }, { title: 'A', isCloseAffordance: true } as vscode.MessageItem, { title: 'B', isCloseAffordance: false } as vscode.MessageItem, { title: 'C', isCloseAffordance: false } as vscode.MessageItem, ); ``` incorrectly generates the same: When all close affordance flags are set to `false` a forth `Cancel` button is added which tells us that the close affordance flag is not ignore altogether.

data.title: SCM viewlet focus colors need work
data.body:
#20999

You cannot tell the difference between an opened diff editor and a focused diff editor line in the viewlet:

Diff editor is opened and focused:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228696/580c9032-f8f2-11e6-8fe9-d5b20f546ade.png)

Diff editor line is focused:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228710/63526d7c-f8f2-11e6-9771-c0b21c17e2e2.png)

Clean button focused (needs more contrast):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228739/82ff023e-f8f2-11e6-86c0-7be8013ec724.png)

.travis.yml is focused, .gitignore is open (this looks like the opposite of what it should be to me):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228764/9b744b9e-f8f2-11e6-9859-f4eff125ff65.png)

---

For reference here's the explorer:

Item focused:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228778/aadd6c6e-f8f2-11e6-8dbd-012073748b72.png)

Editor focused:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228843/dc6e771e-f8f2-11e6-9a44-5aea11d012ac.png)

.travis.yml is focused, .gitignore is open (again this looks like the opposite of what it should be to me, cc @bpasero):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228856/ea9e2604-f8f2-11e6-9702-0505755b40c4.png)

data.title: SCM viewlet click/keyboard navigation doesn't work
data.body:
#20999

Clicking always forces focus in the right-side editor so it's only possible to navigate the viewlet list if you navigate focus there (eg. click commit message and tab to the list).

data.title: Git: Stage gives ambiguous error message
data.body:
#20999

In file with local changes I did Git: Stage via the command palette:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23228435/52bb8ddc-f8f1-11e6-82ca-a6d3b1d21b14.png)

data.title: Is "Clean Changes" the best choice of words?
data.body:
#20999

The words "clean" and "dirty" are more technical than they need to be imo, something like "undo local changes" might be more generally understandable?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23227810/09296c5e-f8ef-11e6-9d8a-3d5d16057c51.png)

It has been a while since I learned the meaning of these words but some developers may not know?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (256d76fed7947e7289f921df10658d7a69233b65, 2017-02-22T07:09:05.746Z) - OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-34-generic - CPUs: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-5500U CPU @ 2.40GHz (4 x 2899) - Memory (System): 11.64GB (1.91GB free) - Memory (Process): 170.14MB working set (170.14MB peak, 101.30MB private, 68.84MB shared) - Load (avg): 1, 1, 1 - VM: 0% - Initial Startup: no - Screen Reader: no - Empty Workspace: no - Timings: |Component|Task|Time (ms)| |---|---|---| |renderer|window.loadUrl() => begin to require(workbench.main.js)|209| |renderer|require(workbench.main.js)|758| |renderer|create extension host => extensions onReady()|869| |renderer|restore viewlet|532| |renderer|restore editor view state|856| |renderer|overall workbench load|1215| |main + renderer|start => extensions ready|1908| |main + renderer|start => workbench ready|2202| --- Testing #20999 When I click on a viewlet button it takes about 500ms to open/hide the viewlet in question. It's instant on stable. Note that the window is otherwise behaving responsively so it's unrelated to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21008 `SplitLinesCollection._constructLines`/`ILineMapperFactory.createLineMapping` seem to be at fault. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23227481/f3cafdba-f8ed-11e6-9c53-abb5304a4d57.png) ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23227662/83b3d816-f8ee-11e6-84b1-4083458a7d2b.png)

data.title: Bug: Terminal shellArgs ignored
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1  f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set User Settings as follows:

    "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.osx": ["-l"],

2. Open terminal view

The terminal seems to be ignoring the shellArgs for the platform.

---

edit: I was able to get it to work with the following...

    "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.osx": ["--init-file", "~/.profile"],

I'm now  unsure if this is an issue with an update to macOS, or if it's related to vscode

data.title: Terminal links: Substrings are considered valid links
data.body:
While testing #21021.

```
bash-3.2$ git remote -v
origin  git@github.com:Microsoft/vscode.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:Microsoft/vscode.git (push)
bash-3.2$
```

`/vscode.git` is detected as link but shouldn't.

data.title: Error when trying to init a git repo
data.body:
#20999

Steps to repro:

1. Open a folder without a git repo
2. Type something in the commit message (not sure if this made a difference)
3. Press init repo button, error
4. Remove message
5. Press init repo button, error

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23226725/79d09378-f8eb-11e6-9a02-0a6ee9a55f85.png)

Git output:

```
Using git 2.9.3 from git
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git

fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git

fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
```
